segments.text: Today we'll have a discussion with Dr. John Eddy of Denton, Texas.
The date is April 7th, 1984.
Today we'll be discussing the Civil Rights Movement during the 50s and 60s and Dr. Eddy's involvement in the activities that went on.
Could you give a general background of your upbringing and how you ended up getting involved in the civil rights movement?
The sources of my involvement in the

So-called civil rights movement in the United States in the 1960s and 70s comes logically out of the United States Constitution, which I studied in the public school systems of the United States, namely in one small high school in Great School, Howard Lake, Minnesota.

As I pursued my work in college and graduate school, in particular studying both science and theology, I began to realize the roots of our culture and Judeo-Christian heritage were support documents for the U.S. Constitution.
the understanding that all men are held equal in the eyes of God and supposedly in the eyes of each other were the basis for my action and attitudes which really

helped me participate in the movement with full understanding that neither the Judeo-Christian heritage nor the U.S. Constitution was being practiced in our society, that there was a great gap between the rhetoric of the Bible and the Constitution
and the actual practice of our people in accepting one another as equals in the area of education, economic opportunity, race, and religious practice.
Growing up in Power Lake, Minnesota, when was your first contact with
peoples of another race?

Well, while our community was predominantly what you might call Anglo-Saxon, white, and Protestant, although there were a significant number of Catholics, there were things that were happening in my life
because of the fact that I lived in America, and America was involved in the world.

While I was born in 1932 in the throes of the Depression, we had all the mass media occurring around, and I was aware of what was happening in the world by listening to radio and television, which occurred during the time I was going to school, which made us aware of
a lot of things, World War II, and then following that, the Korean War, development of human rights and statements in the United Nations.
All of that was occurring while I was in grade school and high school.
So these were big events in the life of anyone who lived during that time.

We had lots of idealists in the state of Minnesota who were primary people who helped create the United Nations, such as Harold Stassen, who was the youngest governor, I believe, in the history of America, who was our youngest governor of Minnesota, and he was a primary mover in the whole
Human Rights Movement worldwide.
Hubert Humphrey was Mayor of Minneapolis and then Senator in the United States Congress and the United States Senate.
And he was an advocate, early advocate of human rights and civil rights for all people and
was with the dominant political party at that time in America, the Democratic Party.

And I would say, and of course Harold Stassen was a Republican, so we had both prominent political leaders in Harold Stassen and Hubert Humphrey, supporters of civil rights, human rights, in both America and in the United Nations throughout the world.
Of course, in addition to that, we had other leaders, such as George McGovern, who was in South Dakota.
And of course, we had another senator,

In addition to that we had many other persons in our political and religious life in Minnesota who supported human rights and civil rights and many of them of course were people who were my pastors as well as my
Christian friends in the colleges that I attended, Hamlin University, St.
Cloud State University, University of Minnesota.
And of course, living only 40 miles from Minneapolis and 60 miles from St. Paul, the capital of Minnesota, I was
aware of many of these things.
In addition to that, my father was an active person in the politics of Minnesota, and he knew, as a Republican, an independent Republican, he knew Harold Stausen and Hubert Humphrey.
He was a leader in the Democratic Party.
And so through my father's
contacts.

I was able to meet many of these political leaders who held strong views on the rights of people and I think this fact that I had this kind of background coming from the state of Minnesota and having a family that was interested in

human and civil rights, having a church, United Methodist Church, that was a leader then and always has been a leader, the tradition of John Wesley, who helped, as many historians will say, probably helped prevent England from having the bloody revolution that France went through because of the many reforms that the followers of John Wesley had in terms of human and civil rights for the English people.
is part of this background.
I go even farther back.
Some of my relatives were involved in the Magna Carta against the king.
Formation of the Magna Carta.
This is a family background and out of the English background that I have in my life.
How did your influence in the Philippines affect you in this area when you returned to the United States?

Well, of course, when I graduated from the University of Minnesota in 1954 in landscape architecture, I was prepared to go as a short-term voluntary missionary to set up an agricultural, medical, educational, and religious center in Mindanao.
at the site which was called Kitapauan.
Interestingly enough, that site, again, had some Minnesota connections.
One of the pastors of Wesley, the church in Minneapolis, Minnesota, had helped select the site and gotten the money for the site.
my campus minister at that time and pastor on the campus.
Wilbur Gross had invited C.L.
Spotswood, who was the director of this project, to our church and he was recruiting people when I heard him speak and that was why I went out there.
The, again, leadership of the United Methodist Church that believes in equality of all people and incidentally
This church has more ethnic group members than any other church in America.
We have the widest range of ethnics in our United Methodist Church.
We're also the first church to have women bishops, which equality of sex for women.
They can even hold the highest leadership in the church.
All of this background of the

disintegration of segregation in terms of race or color or sex was my background when I went into the experience there in the Philippines and of course there we worked as a group of young graduates from colleges in the United States
There were six of us from America and about 12 people from all over the Philippines that worked.
And again, it was like experiencing a multiracial and multicultural group of Christians who were working together on these common problems
The people were suffering from hunger, disease, illiteracy, and also religious problems because religion isn't always a positive experience.
Some religions induce and convey fears and the leaders keep power over the people in a way that would
keep the people under their reign and even keep them ill sometimes in order to keep that power.
So our ministry there was truly a manifestation of this whole idea of treating people equally regardless of their background and trying to help them in developing themselves
in positive ways so that they could help themselves and not be dependent upon any group for particular ways that would harm them in the future.
The experience in the Philippines helped me see that discrimination is not just in America.
It's also there in the Philippines.
It's a worldwide phenomenon.

It helped me also realize what the United Nations Charter idealistically was trying to do and is still trying to do in trying to see all people as people of possibility and working towards that end in every country to help people develop their maximum potential.
help them understand themselves and work in relationship to other people who are different in race, color, creed, background.
It also helped me work with vastly different religious groups, whereas I was in a Judeo-Christian culture in the United States up until that time, for some 22 years now,
I was working in a predominantly Islamic culture.
I was secondly working in a culture where I was in a minority.
As a white person, the majority were of the brown race, Filipinos.
And also that we had a number of Chinese, Japanese.
In other words, we had an Asian majority.
Third, I was working in a culture that was primarily non-technological.
So again, I was a minority here.
I'd been in a highly technological society, and here was primarily agrarian society.
Fourth, the climate was different, whereas I was in a climate that was predominantly northern.
This was a
southern equator, tropical climate.
All these, without going into further detail, it was a vast change, and yet I saw the common threads of humanity.
No matter where we are, there are more things we have in common amongst people than we have, because we all had the same blood type,
human blood is a common factor, and we were all striving to survive in a society that had a lot of, and still does, have a lot of tragic things in its environment.
Coming back from that experience, you felt the
call to go on into the ministry?
Was that, did that experience, was that the causal factor in your decision to go into the ministry, or you had, had you already decided that before you left, to go into the ministry?
Well, I had a call to go into the ministry, if that's the term you want to use, at least
I had a commitment to serve people from about the age of 12 on.
I read a book by David Livingston, his work in Africa, and this greatly affected my understanding of what a person's life ought to be, and of course there was
Livingston was a 19th century product.
But then Elbridge Whiteser is a continuation of that same philosophy in the 20th century.
And these kinds of people, extremely talented people, who were not only

people who were medical doctors but they were musicians and they were writers and they were activists and wanting to improve the world and at the same time give their talents for others even though they probably could have all been millionaires they would have just stopped and concentrated on the things that they had that would have provided money showed me the kind of witness that I think

we all need to have if we're going to have a better world and not just take from the world but to give because we've been given so much in the first place so that I went out with the realization that I wanted to serve and continue and I had the choice either go to seminary or go into
for the graduate work in agriculture.
I had a fellowship at Iowa State, or I had a fellowship at Garrett Theological Seminary.
And so I thought that going to the seminary, I was continuing with the same idea of serving.
The other thing is, I realized that
while I'd been on the missions field and a lot of work there had been very meaningful and this is a good thing to do, that perhaps the biggest mission field in the world was still yet in America.
Because I saw many of the so-called ideas in the U.S. Constitution and in the Old Testament, New Testament,
not being practiced, and yet we were sending missionaries all over the world, and yet we were not giving many of our minorities and ethnic groups in this country equal opportunity.
In other words, I saw a great gap here in hypocrisy between what we said, you know, love thy neighbor as thyself, and not really doing it in our own country
And so I saw a greater missing field in America than I saw in the Philippines or anywhere else in the world.

And of course I came back and had some cultural shock because I felt in re-entry from the Philippines that I'd met some people in the Philippines who were deeper Christians and many of the people that
had sent me out to the Philippines and who I came back to.

I began to realize that Christianity, a deep religious faith, is not the sole possession of any one denomination or any one nation or any one person, but it's universal and that perhaps in some countries of the world
because people are willing to sacrifice more for their faith than maybe even their own country, that we have much to learn from people all over the world and not just in America.
Returning to seminary, what was the attitude in seminary tours like?
What year did you return from the Philippines?
Well, I was just there six months.

I left, graduated in May from the University of Minnesota, and at that time the University of Minnesota was the third largest university in the United States, and then left 10,000 miles to the Philippines, and I was just there from July, or June, to...
January.

So I was just there six months, and January of 1955, I got back to, and I then took a position as a youth minister in Wilmer, Minnesota, and served that until May, and then took a small church in Wright County called Greenwood near Buffalo,
for that summer and then started the seminary in the fall of 1955 as a full-time student.
So what was the...
So you were still in the United States when the Brown versus the Board of Education decision came out about doing that concerning the separate and equal clause, the U.S. Supreme Court.
That's what I talked to Mr. Rogers about yesterday when he was living at that time in Virginia.
What was the attitude towards the Supreme Court decision in the seminary as far as the church believed in equality, but did any sort of activism or support of the need to integrate,
to create an equality that was not separate.
Was there rumblings of that during your seminary years?
Well, there was this all during that period of time in the seminary.
There were numbers of us who would go out to various areas in the Chicago area, where we had as much segregation as it was anywhere in the South, to help integrate
different kinds of situations.

In particular, we saw the school integration go more smoothly than they, of course, were working it in the South, but we saw the housing integration in the Chicago area to be the area where there was the biggest problem.
And so we went out, some of us, and tried to work with some of our seminary professors and other

church leaders and others to try to integrate public housing along with, and of course it wasn't just housing, it was integrating, trying to integrate the parks and recreational areas and of course all of that just didn't occur overnight.
And that's why when Martin Luther came on the scene in the 60s, which was almost another ten years later, we still didn't have all of that accomplished.
And that's why we needed further legislation.
That's what led the march to Washington.
Even with all of the Supreme Court decision, integration of schools, it still didn't affect
other areas of society, such as housing, public accommodations, public transportation.
People were forced to sit in the back of the bus, as the slogan or cliche goes, and not even drink from public water fountains in parts of the South, and so forth.
So, in Evanston, where you lived, was there any
and things like that, having to sit at the back of the bus.
Well, Evanston was a bastion of leadership.
Of course, the Royal Consulate Churches had its meeting there about the same time.
And the leadership of the clergy and the seminary and the seminary students

was strong, I would think that at that time that Garrett Theological Seminary had amongst its, and also the pastor of the local church there, or churches in the plural, that of all communities in America, Evanston probably was one of the strongest communities.
Again, I was fortunate to
In Minnesota, we had the leadership of Harold Stassen, our governor, and Hubert Humphrey, our senator.
Here, the leadership of the seminary professors, and we had lots of older seminary students who had been in World War II and in the Korean War, where they had
been in integrated military outfits and where they had also been in business industry and medicine and other professions and they had worked as people who saw great leadership.
The other thing is a number of my seminary professors had been

in prison camps in world war ii i think of don holter who was in the philippines and i think of my another one philosophy professor who was in in the singapore region and taking courses with them and hearing them uh expound on the faith and this this vision of
human rights, even though they had been greatly persecuted and even almost died under the suffering they occurred under the Japanese during World War II.
It was quite an inspiration.
And of course then we had people studying from all over the world.
Garrett was the largest Methodist seminary at that time

in the world, and again, the Methodist Church being a leader in human rights, civil rights, and having one of the largest missionary programs, not just to send people to preach the gospel, but to live the gospel, and to train people how to live the gospel and preach the gospel.
In a comprehensive program such as I mentioned earlier in the Philippines,
It was a real inspiration to me.
It supported my feeling that this was something I wanted to invest my life in and to help others.
So Evanston was an ideal community, just as Minnesota had before been an ideal state to live in as far as this kind of vision that we're talking about, human rights, civil rights.
and practicing them and carrying them out.
So when did you begin your campus ministry at Mankato State in Minnesota?
Well, I started in 1960.
I was there five years.
At the end of the five years, I had been there longer than any other campus ministry in the state of Minnesota.
During that time, we saw the building of a building
and almost had it paid off by the time I left.
I went on to graduate school at Southern Illinois University, following that work.
During those five years, we did many things.
Again, I saw some of the whole theme.
Again, we worked with civil rights movements in the South, myself, our students, going to Mississippi,
a number of us doing different kinds of things, working in colleges, working in civil rights, voter registration.
It's quite a paradox and irony.
Here we have a U.S. Constitution.
A lot of people couldn't vote.
They had to pay a poll tax to vote.
To me, unbelievable and incredible that we would claim ourselves to be a democracy and not
and a chance for our people to vote and assert their democratic rights.
And I saw this very definitely as a hardcore democracy, and I know that some of our people that have believed in this have been called communists.
To me, this is the worst thing in the world that you could call a true patriot of this country, a true democratic.
And I'm not talking about Democratic Party because it's political.
Political is not a part of it, but it's political in a sense of the constitutional rights and the bill of rights that I'm talking about here, true patriotism and that kind of democracy.
And so that kind of thing we did in the campus ministry, plus we worked in mental hospitals again.
early work in mental hospitals to make the mental hospitals more humane along the miniature idea of caring and sharing.
And so we went into mental hospitals.
Our students, again, I worked with them to make these mental patients feel that they were lovable and usable and to get them out of that institutional setting.
And I think that was a real breakthrough that I was involved in.
And again, I worked in the inner cities.
inner city movement to help revitalize our cities, to make them livable, very important thing.
And again, Indian reservations in the rural area, again to work in ways to revitalize the rural areas, many of the Indians suffering from alcoholism, depression.
with a similar factor in inner city amongst a lot of people, alcoholism, drug addiction, depression.
And so I felt during that time that I was able to do a lot of things that are still needed and will always be needed because of the very nature of our society.
And those things helped formulate my present concerns and interests that I continue in some way today.
Well,
So some of your students did go on the voter registration drives, and was there a sizable percentage of black students at Mankato State?
We didn't have too many black students at Mankato State, but we did have some black students,
Mexican-American students, some Asian-American students, and we had a large number of international students.
In other words, one doesn't need to have a particular large American minority if there are other groups.
To give you this feeling that we need to work on this, not just in America, but worldwide, this idea
civil rights, civil freedom, civil rights.

The fact that we took into our home international students who felt discriminated in Mankato because of the color of their skin and because they were, quote, foreign, is an indication that, again, this whole idea that our society
It has a lot of churches and synagogues and parishes.
The people haven't really gotten the message of Jesus, who found discrimination there amongst the people, amongst the Jewish people.
The Pharisees, the Zealots, the Sadducees were all discriminating each other, and yet they were part of the same religious group, which is tragic.

And then, of course, there was a great discrimination in Jesus' time between the Samaritans and the people, Jewish people, and, of course, others, which indicates the total problem of prejudice and discrimination is a broad thing.
It can happen within religious groups as well as within color groups that are all the same color as well as
amongst people who had the same so-called political ideology.
When didyou went down to Mississippi in the spring of 1963?
Yes, I had an opportunity to bewe arranged an exchange between the chaplain of Rust College, which is the oldest Methodist black college in the United States,
formed shortly after the Civil War, 1866.
And incidentally, at the site of which there were over 59 different battles fought between the Confederate or Southern and the Northern or Union forces.
And the chaplain there came to Mankato.
He lived in our house.
We lived in his house.
I taught the classes he taught.
He taught classes that I taught.
He did the work of ministry that I did.
I did the work of ministry he did.
It was that kind of exchange, and we gained a lot, both of us, in understanding.
Here was, I was in a predominantly black group.
He was, as a white person, and he as a
predominantly black was in a community of predominantly whites.
What kind of response did you get from black students and teachers?
Well, I received a very warm response from the black students and faculty and local church
From the white people in that community, they saw us as being a problem.
We were the nigger lovers.
We were the carpetbaggers.
We were the northern renegades.
We were the people who were there to disrupt their environment.
because it meant then if the ideas that we lived and believed came into being, that their public facilities, public transportation, their voting systems would be equal to all Americans.
And this was an extreme threat to their understanding of what American democracy was all about.
preaching in his church differently, and working with their students differently, than working with the students in Minnesota?
Well, because Russ College did not have the highest academic standards that Mankato State University had, again because of black students that had inferior educational opportunities,
The schools were not as well integrated, you see, because this was ten years after the Brown versus whatever Board of Education decision.
We still didn't see the fruits of equal opportunity in education there.
And so I saw that the students just were not as well prepared for one thing, orally or written.
And on the other hand, they had a Christian tradition that made them kind and more caring than many of the students in the so-called, in the predominantly white university in Mankato.

So there are different kinds of things here because of the limitations of education and also the emphasis of the Southern Church on religion and as a more encompassing part of one's life and one's family.
There was a secularization
faith, at least in the North, and I think it's even more common all over, was evident.
Had the groups at West College attempted any sit-ins or other...?
The College was conservative, but individuals in the student body were doing things
to help create more democratic options.
It's classed in Memphis, right?
Right.
Russ College was not a center of civil rights activism.
It was probably a very average
conservative black college at that time.

Now though just a few miles away at the University of Mississippi we had James Meredith captive in a residence hall there and we went over there to visit and of course army tanks were going around the residence hall and troops were marching for one man to go to school, to protect one man to go to school.

they had the National Guard out, with machine guns and tanks, and it was an unbelievable display of military power, and again, this just blew my mind that this could happen in America, and I thought about all the history books I'd read in Minnesota, and all the other things, and how I really didn't understand what was happening in my own country,
with the reaction that people had to one man who was trying to get an education at a public university in Mississippi.

Now, of course, as we look back on that, it seems just very strange because the outstanding people at the University of Mississippi are black athletes who play on a football team, and they're proud of them now.
It's such a strange reversal.
It's unbelievable.
And this is 1985.
That was 1963.
And of course, in 22 years, that's a big jump from blacks being denied an education to blacks being recruited, going out to try to get the black athletes
so that they can have the best football team in the country.
And really, things have changed very much, though, if you think about it, because in those situations, the blacks are being put upon, or used in a way.
Well, I agree.
I think, again, the black athlete is being exploited, so why?
the television can project these games and some coaches can win and get big salaries and some professional teams can use the colleges as feeders for their teams.
Sure, I see the whole, when you go back to the gladiator times of the Romans and you wonder, you know, what have we
done in 2,000 years.
Same kind of crass commercialism, bloodthirsty crowds, and callous kinds of crass commercialism again occurring here.
And the black athlete has exchanged his status
of a slave picking cotton to a robot running down the field.
But at least his status, if he remains healthy, doesn't get sucked into drugs and other problems, is that he might eventually become a person who can use his power and influence to make it
make this a better country, maybe more idealistic than whatever.
But I like to think that some of them will give back some things and help change this.
Considering Russ Colleges and Methodist institution-wide, what was the funding for Russ College?
Did it come from Methodists?
congregations all over the country, or is it just parted?
